Award.AwardTitle: The Kepler Cluster Study: Planets and Gyrochronology
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will use data obtained from the Kepler satellite to search for transiting planets in open star clusters. All data are already obtained. One of the main goals is to improve the accuracy of stellar ages using stellar rotation techniques(gyrochronology), which has applications to other fields of stellar astronomy. This work will be used to constrain planet formation models in open star clusters.

Broader impacts of the work include making the data publicly available and training undergraduate students in research, including experience with reduction and analysis of stellar spectra for stellar properties, radial-velocities, and binary star orbits, and with time-series photometric data for transiting planets and stellar variability(rotation).

POR.DRECONTENT:
A star cluster is a dense group of stars born at the same time and place, traveling through the Galaxy held together by their mutual gravity. They are a special and very valuable class of objects in astronomy. This is primarily because we can determine the shared age and distance of their member stars with high precision and good accuracy. The ages of most other stars, not in clusters and drifting through space in relative isolation - like our Sun, are much more difficult to determine, and so are the ages of potential planets orbiting them.

Knowing the ages of stars is critically important for studying the evolution of most astronomical phenomena, including the formation and evolution of planets and planetary systems. Not only will finding planets and planetary systems around stars in clusters give the ages of such systems, but the crowded stellar environment in clusters also provide an opportunity to explore the effect of a high stellar density on the formation, evolution, and survival of planets and planetary systems.

The Kepler Open Cluster Study (KeCS) was designed to take advantage of large telescopes on Earth as well as the very precise measurements from NASA's Kepler space telescope to search for transiting planets and measure stellar spin-periods. The objects of interest for KeCS was four rich star clusters within the field of view of Kepler. Specifically, the main goals of KeCS were:

1) To construct and calibrate a new "astronomical clock" that could give reliable ages for any star based on a measurement of it's spin-velocity (gyrochronology).

2) To study the effect of a crowded stellar environment on the nature and frequency of planets, and test the hypothesis that planets cannot form, or form differently, around stars in clusters.

The inherent benefits of star clusters can only be exploited to reach the goals of KeCS if samples of stars are identified as secure members of the clusters. To accomplish this, the first several years of KeCS were spent conducting observations of the four Kepler clusters from large Earth-based telescopes, to identify their member stars among the thousands of foreground and background pretenders. For each identified cluster member, the measurements from the Kepler space telescope were used to search for planetary transits and for measuring stellar spin-periods. The combined information about cluster membership (and thus stellar age), planets, and stellar spin, laid the foundation for the main results of KeCS:

1) KeCS successfully measured the spin-periods of members of the 1 billion year old cluster NGC 6811. These measurements nearly doubled the age-range for reliable spin-periods from 600 million years (in the Hyades cluster). KeCS thereby took a major step toward establishing an empirical relationship between stellar age and spin, and thus toward calibrating the technique of gyrochronology. These first result were published in the Astrophysical Journal Letters.

2) KeCS then detected the first and (at the time) only known transiting planets
in a star cluster. The two planets, found orbiting Sun-like stars in the cluster NGC 6811, were both smaller than the planet Neptune in our solar system, and the smallest known cluster planets. This discovery showed that small planets can form and survive in the dense and hostile cluster environment for at least 1 billion years, and subsequent statistical analysis implied that the frequency and properties of planets in clusters are consistent with those of planets found around isolated non-cluster (field) stars in the Galaxy. These exciting results were published in the journal Nature.

3) KeCS culminated with another important step toward establishing the empirical relationship between stellar spin-period and age, when it measured spin-periods for members of the 2.5 billion year old cluster NGC 6819. The spin-periods in NGC 6819, combined with those in the 1 billion year old NGC 6811, and in younger clusters, traced a well-defined relationship between spin and age, and thus further established and calibrated the technique of gyrochronology. These important results were also published in the journal Nature.

With the comprehensive work on establishing membership, surveying for planets, and measuring rotation periods in the Kepler clusters, KeCS laid the foundation for several spin-off projects and collaborations with students, postdocs, and senior colleagues both within the US and abroad. The PI is grateful to the National Science Foundation for the generous support of this project.
